content.text: Place the metre rule with the pivot below the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark. **The pivot must stay in this position for the duration of the experiment.**
Place block U on the metre rule with its centre at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark
Place block M on the metre rule on the other side of the pivot as shown in Fig. 1.1. Adjust the position of block M until the metre rule is as near to being balanced as possible
The distance a between the centre of block U and the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark has been recorded in Table 1.1
In Table 1.1, record the position of block M
Calculate the distance \(b\) between the centre of block U and the centre of block M, using the equation:

content.blockMath: \[b = (\text{position of block M} - \text{position of block U}).\]

content.text: Repeat the procedure for positions of block U at the \(10.0 \text{cm}\), \(15.0 \text{cm}\), \(20.0 \text{cm}\) and \(25.0 \text{cm}\) marks
Plot a graph of \(b / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(a / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). You do not need to start the axis at the origin (0,0)
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
G =
Calculate the mass \(M_{\mathrm{U}}\) of block U using the equation \(M_{\mathrm{U}} = (G - 1) \times k\), where \(k = 200 \mathrm{~g}\)
Record the value of \(M_{\mathrm{U}}\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
Describe why it is difficult to place the block U at the correct mark on the metre rule each time. Explain how you overcame this difficulty. You may draw a diagram
It is difficult to balance the metre rule in this type of experiment
Describe how to adjust the position of block M on the metre rule until the metre rule is as close to balance as possible
You may draw a diagram if it helps your explanation
In this experiment, you will determine the mass of a block U by a balancing method
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Use one of the thermometers to measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
Pour \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water into the glass tube
Pour \(300 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
In the first row of Table 2.1, for \(t = 0\), record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{C}}\) of the water in the glass tube and the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the water in the beaker
Place the glass tube in the beaker and immediately start the stopclock

Record, in Table 2.1, the temperatures \(\theta_{\mathrm{C}}\) of the water in the glass tube and the temperatures \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the water in the beaker at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(60 \text{s}\), \(90 \text{s}\), \(120 \text{s}\), \(150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\)
Complete the headings and the time column in the table
State what you expect the temperature of the water in the glass tube will be when \(\theta_{\mathrm {C}}\) stops rising
Justify your answer by reference to your readings
statement
justification
State what you expect the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm {H}}\) of the water in the beaker will be after a few hours
\(\theta_{\mathrm {H}}=\)
Suggest two changes that could be made to the apparatus or the procedure to ensure that the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm {C}}\) of the cold water in the glass tube rises more quickly
In this experiment, you will investigate the transfer of thermal energy between hot water in a beaker and cold water in a glass tube
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
The glass tube must remain in the clamp throughout the experiment
Switch on
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the current \(I\) in the circuit
Use the voltmeter to measure and record the potential difference \(V\) across resistor X
Disconnect the voltmeter
Connect the voltmeter to measure the potential difference \(V\) across the combination of resistors X and Y
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the current \(I\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V\) across the combination of resistors X and Y
Disconnect the voltmeter
Connect the voltmeter to measure the potential difference \(V\) across the combination of resistors X, Y and Z
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the current \(I\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V\) across the combination of resistors X, Y and Z
Switch off
Complete the headings in Table 3.1
A student suggests that the current should remain constant when the voltmeter is used to measure potential differences across the different combinations of resistors
State whether your readings support this suggestion
Justify your answer by reference to your readings
statement
justification
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the resistance \(R\) of each combination of resistors
Use your readings from Table 3.1 and the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
For resistors in series, the total resistance of the combination is the sum of the individual resistances
Use your results from Table 3.1 to calculate the resistances \(R_{\mathrm{Y}}\) and \(R_{\mathrm{Z}}\) of resistors Y and Z
\(R_{\mathrm{Y}} =\)
\(R_{\mathrm{Z}} =\)
The circuit components are to be rearranged so that
resistors X, Y and Z are in parallel
the ammeter will measure the current in the circuit
the voltmeter will measure the potential difference across the resistors
In the space below, draw a diagram of this circuit
Set up the circuit as described in (e)
Switch on. Measure and record the current \(I_{\mathrm{p}}\) in the circuit and the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) across the resistors
Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the resistors in parallel. Use your readings and the equation \(R_{\mathrm{p}} = \frac{V_{\mathrm{p}}}{I_{\mathrm{p}}}\)
In this experiment, you will investigate a circuit containing different resistors
The circuit has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
A student wants to investigate the factors that affect the height to which a ball bounces when it is dropped
Plan an experiment that will enable him to investigate in detail how the height from which a ball is dropped affects how high it bounces
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment
The apparatus available includes:
balls of different materials and sizes
sheets of different floor coverings
Write a plan for the experiment
In your plan, you should:
list any additional apparatus needed
explain briefly how you would carry out the experiment
describe a precaution which could be taken to ensure that measurements of the height of bounce are reliable
state the key variables that you would control
draw a table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how you could analyse your readings to reach a conclusion
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
